title: Simple Steps to Make Your Mac Boot from a Flash Drive

steps.title: Download the Mac OS X Lion Installer from the App Store.
steps.content: Download the Mac OS X Lion Installer from the App Store. The latest versions of the Mac operating system are only available through the App Store.

steps.title: The download can take some time depending on your internet connection.
steps.content: The download can take some time depending on your internet connection. Don't worry if you lose connection halfway through download, it will resume as soon as you are re-connected to the App Store.

steps.title: Make a backup of the installer you downloaded from App Store and save it on your desktop.
steps.content: Make a backup of the installer you downloaded from App Store and save it on your desktop. Under no condition should you work on the original installer file.

steps.title: Use the backup file to make a bootable USB drive.
steps.content: Use the backup file to make a bootable USB drive.

steps.title: Right-click on the installer file and click on "Show Package Contents".
steps.content: Right-click on the installer file and click on "Show Package Contents".

steps.title: This will open a new window with the contents of the installer file.
steps.content: This will open a new window with the contents of the installer file.

steps.title: Navigate to Contents » SharedSupport.
steps.content: Navigate to Contents » SharedSupport.

steps.title: You’ll see a disk image called “InstallESD.dmg.”
steps.content: You’ll see a disk image called “InstallESD.dmg.” This is your ticket to creating a bootable copy of OSX Mountain Lion.

steps.title: Click on the magnifying glass icon in the menu bar and type "Disk Utility".
steps.content: Click on the magnifying glass icon in the menu bar and type "Disk Utility".

steps.title: Click on "Disk Utility" Application and wait for it to open.
steps.content: Click on "Disk Utility" Application and wait for it to open.

steps.title: Drag the “InstallESD.dmg” file from installer folder into the white box on the left side of Disk Utility, and the disk image will be added.
steps.content: Drag the “InstallESD.dmg” file from installer folder into the white box on the left side of Disk Utility, and the disk image will be added.

steps.title: Connect your USB drive to the Mac using the provided USB slots.
steps.content: Connect your USB drive to the Mac using the provided USB slots.

steps.title: Wait for it to be recognized and displayed on the desktop.
steps.content: Wait for it to be recognized and displayed on the desktop.

steps.title: Select the USB drive from the list in Disk Utility.
steps.content: Select the USB drive from the list in Disk Utility.

steps.title: Click on Erase.
steps.content: Click on Erase .

steps.title: Ensure it’s partitioned as “Mac OS Extended (Journaled)” under the “Partition” section in Disk Utility.
steps.content: Ensure it’s partitioned as “Mac OS Extended (Journaled)” under the “Partition” section in Disk Utility.

steps.title: The name will be "Untitled" by default, you are free to change it as per your liking.
steps.content: The name will be "Untitled" by default, you are free to change it as per your liking.

steps.title: Click on Erase in the bottom right corner.
steps.content: Click on Erase in the bottom right corner.

steps.title: Wait for USB disk to be erased and restored to single clean and usable partition.
steps.content: Wait for USB disk to be erased and restored to single clean and usable partition.

steps.title: Click on the InstallESD.dmg icon on the left side of Disk Utility app.
steps.content: Click on the InstallESD.dmg icon on the left side of Disk Utility app.

steps.title: Click on the Restore tab in the center-top part of Disk Utility App.
steps.content: Click on the Restore tab in the center-top part of Disk Utility App. “InstallESD.dmg” should already be present in the source tab.

steps.title: Drag the drive you just added to Disk Utility from the source list in the top left of the app white space to the “Destination” path.
steps.content: Drag the drive you just added to Disk Utility from the source list in the top left of the app white space to the “Destination” path.

steps.title: Hit Restore and let Disk Utility work its magic.
steps.content: Hit Restore and let Disk Utility work its magic. This can take some time so please be patient.

steps.title: Close Disk Utility.
steps.content: Close Disk Utility. You now have a bootable USB disk drive with Mac OS X Mountain Lion installed and good to go!

steps.title: Restart the computer you wish to boot from this disk.
steps.content: Restart the computer you wish to boot from this disk.

steps.title: While restarting, hold down the ⌥ Option key.
steps.content: While restarting, hold down the ⌥ Option key.

steps.title: Select the Installer app from the menu and you will be able to boot from it.
steps.content: Select the Installer app from the menu and you will be able to boot from it.

steps.title: Congratulations!
steps.content: Congratulations! You can now use this disk to verify/repair disk partitions, repair current installed OSX, upgrade to new OSX, or perform a clean install of existing or better OSX.
